determined by viral DNA extraction followed by plaque assays, adsorption assays, and electrophoresis of PCR products. theaflavins are a dimer of different catechins in green tea extract. green tea extract contains a relatively high amount of catechins compared to black tea. green tea extract contains a relatively high amount of catechins as compared to black tea. concentrated theaflavin extracts made from black tea can be just as effective as catechins. it is believed that the high number of hydroxyl groups of theaflavins is responsible for its antioxidative properties. it has been found that theaflavins are capable of inhibiting certain types of cancer [10], as well as inhibiting viruses, including bovine rotavirus and bovine coronavirus [11], HIV-1 [12,13], and three different PCR was used to compare the relative levels of total DNA produced by infection with untreated and untreated HSV-1. there was approximately a 75% reduction in the concentration of DNA in cells following treatment with 1.4 mM BTE. gel electrophoresis of the PCR products from DNA resulted in visible bands on the gel corresponding to viral genes for glycoprotein D (gD), GFP and pUL46. column 1 contains the DNA ladder, with visible bands identified to the left in base pairs (bp). column 2 and 5, 3 and 6, 4 and 7 contain DNA amplified with primers for the HSV-1 gD and pUL46 genes. 549 cells exposed to media only, A549 cells exposed to media and A549 cells exposed to HSV-1 and BTE. A549 cells were treated with BTE before being exposed to HSV-1. black tea extracts have previously been found to block the production of free radicals and inhibit the growth of cancerous cells. a green tea catechin, EGCG, has already been shown to inhibit HSV-1. theaflavins are more stable at pH 7 than EC and EGCG. fluorescent microscopy and plaque assays demonstrated that BTE significantly inhibited the infectious cycle of HSV-1 in cultured cells. treatment with BTE for one hour significantly reduced viral titers but did not inactivate the virions. BTE concentrations up to 1.4 mM can be used to treat cells infected by HSV-1. lower cost of BTE, as compared to pure theaflavins, make it attractive for consideration as a safe and effective antiviral agent. authors declare that they have no competing interests.
